entry.title: Ted Talk-2
entry.content: This is the 2nd episode of my Ted Talk Subtitle Series, and the topic today is about Love, a story of a woman, finding out what is happending to her while she can not get out of sorrow, by megnetic resonance test. Can we choose to fall out of love 1. First part introduce the background of herself. Hello, my name is Dessa, and I am a member of a hip-hop collective called Doomtree. I am the one in the tank top. And I make my living as a performing, touring rapper and singer. When we perform as a collective, this is what our shows look like. I am the one in the boots. Thereâ€™s a lot of jumping. Thereâ€™s a lot of sweating. Itâ€™s loud. Itâ€™s high-energy. Sometimes there are unintentional body checks onstage. Sometimes there are completely intentional body checks onstage. Itâ€™s kind of a hybrid between an intramuralï¼ˆinternal hockeyï¼ˆæ›²æ£çƒ game and a concert. 2. And then show us the reason why the speaker need to do the following test. However, when I perform my own music as a solo artist, I tend to gravitate(å—å¸å¼•) towards more melancholy(sorrow) sounds. A few years ago, I gave my mom the rough mixes of a new album, and she said, â€œBaby, itâ€™s beautiful, but why is it always so sad?â€ â€œYou always make music to bleed out too.â€ And I thought,â€Who are you hanging out with that you know that phrase?â€ But over the course of my career, Iâ€™ve written so many sad love songs that I got messages like this from fans:â€Release new music or a book. I need help with my breakup.â€ And after performing and recording and touring those songs for a long time, I found myself in a position in which my professional niche(åˆé€‚çš„å·¥ä½œ) was essentially romantic devastation(ç ´å). What I hadnâ€™t been public about, however, was the fact that most of these songs had been written about the same guy. And for 2 years, we tried to sort ourselves out, and for 5, and on and off for 10. And I was not only heart broken, but I was kind of embarrassed that I couldnâ€™t rebound from what other people seemed to recover from so regularly. And even though I knew it wasnâ€™t doing either of us any good, I just couldnâ€™t figure out how to put the love down. 3. Tell us the procedure of the magnetic resonance(ç£å…±æŒ¯) test. Then, drinking white wine one night, I saw a Ted Talk by a woman named Dr. Halen Fisher, and she said in her work, sheâ€™d been able to map the coordinates of love in the human brain. And I thought, well, if I could find my love in my brain, maybe I could get it out. So I went to twitter. â€œAnybody got access to an fMRI lab, like at midnight or something? Iâ€™ll trade for backstage(åŽå°) passes and whiskey.â€ And thatâ€™s Dr. Sheryl Olman, who works at the university of Minnesotaâ€™s center for magnetic resonance research. She took me up on it. I explained Dr. Fisherâ€™s protocol, and we decided to recreate it with a sample size of one, me. So I got decked out in a pair of forest green scrubs(ç£¨ç ‚è†), and I was laid on a gurney(ä¼ é€æž¶) and wheeled into an fMRI machine. 4. The machenic of a fMRI machine. If youâ€™re unfamiliar with that technology, essentially, a fMRI machine is a big, tubular(like a tube) magnet that tracks the progress of deoxygenated iron in your blood. So it essentially figuring out what parts of your brain are making the biggest metabolic(æ–°é™ˆä»£è°¢) demand at any given moment. And in that way, it can figure out which structures are associated with a task, like tapping your finger, for example, always light up the same region, or in my case, looking at pictures of your ex-boyfriend, and then looking at a picture of a dude who just sort of resembled(like) my ex-boyfriend but for whom I had no strong feelings. He was the control. 5. Use examples to explain the result of the test. And when I left the machine, we had these really high resolution images of my brain. We could cleave(cut) the two halves apart. we can inflate(å……æ°”) the cortex(è„‘çš®å±‚) to see inside all of the wrinkles, essentially, in a view that Dr. Cheryl Olman called the â€œbrain skin rugâ€. And we could see how my brain had behaved when I looked at images of both men. And this was important. We could track all of the activity when I looked at the control and when I looked at my ex. And it was in comparing these data sets that weâ€™d be able to find the love alone, in the same way that, if I were to step on a scale fully dressed and then step on it again naked, the difference between those numbers would be the weight of my clothing. So when we did that data comparison, we subtracted one from the other, we fount activity in exactly the regions Dr. Fisher would have predicted. Thatâ€™s me. And thatâ€™s my brain in love. There was activity in that little orange dot, the ventral tegmental area, that kind of loop of red is the anterior cingulate and that golden set of horns(è§’) is the caudates. After she had had time to analyze the data with her team and a couple of partners, Andrea and Phil, Cheryl sent me an image, a single slide. It was my brain in cross section, with one bright dot of activity that represented my feelings for this dude. And Iâ€™d known I was in love, and thatâ€™s the whole reason I was going to these outrageous(hard to believe) lengths. But having an image that proved it felt like such a vindication, like, yeah itâ€™s all in my head but now I know exactly where. And I also felt like assassin(murderer) who had her mark. Thatâ€™s what I had to annihilate(destroy). 6. The procedure of training her brain. So I decided to embark(begin) on a course of treatment called â€œneurofeedbackâ€. I worked with a woman named Penijean Gracefire, and she explained that what weâ€™d be doing was training my brain. entry.title: Ted Talk Subtitles
entry.content: From today, I am going to listen Ted Talk every day. No matter how long one episode is, I will listen and take notes on 3 minutes of that episode. I have calculated it that it takes me about an hour to finish this daily listening task. And here is the First Ted Talk that I am going to share, it is about climate change. How climate change affects your mental health?â€“Britt Wray For all thatâ€™s ever been said about climate change, we havenâ€™t heard nearly enough about the psychological impacts of living in a warming world.If youâ€™ve heard the grim(serious) climate research that science communicators like me weave(put together) into our books and documentaries, youâ€™ve probably felt bouts(period of activity) of fear, fatalism or hopelessness.If youâ€™ve been impacted by climate disaster, these feelings can set in much deeper, leading to shock, trauma(state of shock), strained(tense) relationships, substance abuse, and the loss of personal identity and control.Vital political and technological work is underway to moderate our climate chaos, but Iâ€™m here to evoke a feeling in you for why we also need our actions and policies to reflect an understanding of how our changing environments threaten our mental, social, and spiritual well-being(health).The anxiety, grief(sorrow) and depression of climate scientists and activists have been reported on for years.Trends weâ€™ve seen after extreme weather events like hurricane Sandy or Katrina for increased PTSD and suicidality.And there are rich mental-health data from northern communities where warming is the fastest, like the Inuit in Labrador, who face existential distress as they witness the ice, a big part of their identity, vanishing before their eyes.Now if that werenâ€™t enough, the American Psychological Association says that our psychological response to our climate change, like conflict avoidance, helplessness, and resignation(departure), are growing.This means that our conscious(aware) and unconscious(unaware) mental processes are holding us back from identifying the causes of the problem for what they are, working on solutions and fostering(encourage/promote) our own psychological resilience(recover), but we need all those things to take on what weâ€™ve created.Lately, Iâ€™ve been studying a phenomenon thatâ€™s just one example of the emotional hardships that weâ€™re seeing.And it comes in the form of a question that a significant amount of people in my generation are struggling to answer.That being: Should I have a child in the age of climate change? After all, any child born today will have to live in a world where hurricanes, flooding, wildfiresâ€”-what we used to call natural disastersâ€”-have become commonplace.The hottest 20 years on record occurred within the last 22.The UN expects that two-thirds of the global population may face water shortage only six years from now.The World Bank predicts that by 2050, there is going to be 140 million climate refugees in sub-Saharan Africa, Latin America and South Asia.And other estimates put that number at over 1 billion.Mass migrations and resources scarcity increase the risk for violence, war and political instability.The UN has just reported that we are pushing up to a million species to extinction, many within decades, and our emission are still increasing even after the Paris Agreement.Over the last year and a half, Iâ€™ve been conducting workshops and interviews with hundreds of people about parenting in the climate crisis.And I can tell you that people who are worried about having kids because of climate change are not motivated by an ascetic(austere/severe) pride. Theyâ€™re nerve-racked.Thereâ€™s even a movement called BirthStrike, whose member have declared that theyâ€™re not going to have kids because of the state of the ecological crisis and inaction from governments to address this existential threat.And yes, other generations have also faced their own apocalyptic dangers, but that is no reason to disregard the very real threat to our survival now.Some feel that itâ€™s better to adopt children. Or that itâ€™s unethical to have more than one, especially three, four or more, because kids increase greenhouse gas emissions.Now, it is a really unfortunate state of affairs when people who want kids sacrifice their right to, because, somehow, they have been told that their lifestyle choices are to blame when the fault is far more systemic, but letâ€™s just unpack the logic here.So an oft-cited study shows that, on average, having one less child in an industrialized nation can save about 59 tons of carbon dioxide per year. While in comparison, living car-free saves nearly 2.5 tons, avoiding a transatlantic(trans-Atlantic) flight â€” and this is just one - saves about 1.5 tons, and eating a plant-based diet can save almost one ton per year. And consider that a Bangladeshi child only add 56 metric tons of carbon to their parentsâ€™ carbon legacy over their lifetime, while an American child, in comparison, adds 9441 to theirs. So this is why some people argue that it is parents from nations with huge carbon footprints should think the hardest about how many kids they have. But the decision to have a child and oneâ€™s feeling about the future are deeply personal. And wrapped up in all sorts of cultural norms, religious beliefs, socioeconomic status, educational levels and more. And so to some, this debate about kids in the climate crisis can seem like it came from another planet. Many have more immediate threats to their survival to think about, like, how theyâ€™re going to put food on the table, when theyâ€™re a single mom working three jobs, or they are HIV positive or on the move in a migrant caravan(moving house car). Tragically, though, climate change is really great at intersectionality. It multiplies the stresses marginalized communities already face. A political scientist once said to me that a leading indicator that climate change is starting to hit home, psychologically, would be an increase in the rate of informed women deciding not to have children. Interesting. Is it hitting home with you, psychologically? Are you perhaps someone with climate-linked pre-traumatic(emotional distressing) stress? A climate psychiatrist(ç²¾ç¥žç—…ä¸“å®¶) coined that term, and thatâ€™s a profession now, by the way, shrink for climate woes(trouble/problem). They are getting work at a time when some high schoolers donâ€™t want to apply to university any longer, because they canâ€™t foresee a future for themselves. And this brings me back to my main point. The growing concerns about having kids in the climate crisis is an urgent indicator of how hard-presses people are feeling.Right now students around the world are screaming for change in the piercing voice of despair. And the fact that we can see how we contribute to this problem that makes us feel unsafe is crazy-making in itself. Climate change is all-encompassing and so are the ways that it messes with our minds. Many activists will tell you that the best antidote(medicine) to grief(sorrow) is activism. And some psychologists will tell you the answer can be found in therapy. Others believe the key is to imagine youâ€™re on your deathbed(end point of your life), reflecting back on whatâ€™s mattered the most in your life, so you can identify what you should do more of now, with the time that you have left. We need all these ideas and more, to take care of our innermost selves, as the environments weâ€™ve known become more punishing towards us. And whether you have children or not, we need to be honest about what is happening, and what we owe one another. We cannot to afford to treat the psychological impacts of climate change as some afterthought(thought of later), because the other issues, of science, technology and the politics and economy, feel hard, while this somehow feels soft. Mental health need to be an integral part of any climate change survival strategy, requiring funding, and ethics of equity and care, and widespread awareness. Because even if youâ€™re the most emotionally avoidant person on the planet, thereâ€™s no rug in the world thatâ€™s big enough to sweep this up under. Thank you.
